item.dc:creator: @darscape darscape
item.description:
@darscape wrote:

If you have not read it, this provides valuable insight on indexes.

Simple Talk – 25 Nov 08

SQL Server Index Basics - Simple Talk

Given the fundamental importance of indexes in databases, it always comes as a surprise how often the proper design of indexes is neglected. It often turns out that the programmer understands detail, but not the broad picture of what indexes do. Bob...

item.dc:creator: @KO9 KO9
item.description:
@KO9 wrote:

mysql> describe SELECT * -> FROM `rscd_invitems` -> WHERE `user` -> IN ( -> -> SELECT `user` -> FROM `rscd_players` -> WHERE `login_ip` = '192.168.1.102' -> ); +----+--------------------+---------------+----------------+---------------+------+---------+------+--------+-------------+ | id | select_type | table | type | possible_keys | key | key_len | ref | rows | Extra | +----+--------------------+---------------+----------------+---------------+------+---------+------+--------+-------------+ | 1 | PRIMARY | rscd_invitems | ALL | NULL | NULL | NULL | NULL | 379370 | Using where | | 2 | DEPENDENT SUBQUERY | rscd_players | index_subquery | user | user | 257 | func | 1 | Using where | +----+--------------------+---------------+----------------+---------------+------+---------+------+--------+-------------+ 2 rows in set (0.01 sec)
mysql> describe SELECT rscd_invitems.* FROM `rscd_players` left join (rscd_invitems) on (rscd_players.user = rscd_invitems.user) WHERE `login_ip` = '127.0.0.1'; +----+-------------+---------------+------+---------------+------+---------+------------------------+-------+-------------+ | id | select_type | table | type | possible_keys | key | key_len | ref | rows | Extra | +----+-------------+---------------+------+---------------+------+---------+------------------------+-------+-------------+ | 1 | SIMPLE | rscd_players | ALL | NULL | NULL | NULL | NULL | 52386 | Using where | | 1 | SIMPLE | rscd_invitems | ref | user | user | 257 | rsca.rscd_players.user | 8 | | +----+-------------+---------------+------+---------------+------+---------+------------------------+-------+-------------+ 2 rows in set (0.00 sec)
mysql> show index from rscd_invitems; +---------------+------------+----------+--------------+-------------+-----------+-------------+----------+--------+------+------------+---------+ | Table | Non_unique | Key_name | Seq_in_index | Column_name | Collation | Cardinality | Sub_part | Packed | Null | Index_type | Comment | +---------------+------------+----------+--------------+-------------+-----------+-------------+----------+--------+------+------------+---------+ | rscd_invitems | 1 | user | 1 | user | A | 47421 | NULL | NULL | | BTREE | | +---------------+------------+----------+--------------+-------------+-----------+-------------+----------+--------+------+------------+---------+ 1 row in set (0.00 sec)

mysql> show index from rscd_players;
±-------------±-----------±---------±-------------±------------±----------±------------±---------±-------±-----±-----------±--------+
| Table | Non_unique | Key_name | Seq_in_index | Column_name | Collation | Cardinality | Sub_part | Packed | Null | Index_type | Comment |
±-------------±-----------±---------±-------------±------------±----------±------------±---------±-------±-----±-----------±--------+
| rscd_players | 0 | PRIMARY | 1 | id | A | 52386 | NULL | NULL | | BTREE | |
| rscd_players | 1 | user | 1 | user | A | 52386 | NULL | NULL | | BTREE | |
±-------------±-----------±---------±-------------±------------±----------±------------±---------±-------±-----±-----------±--------+
2 rows in set (0.00 sec)

They are selecting the same fields, however the join concats both tables into one then runs a normal where query, whereas the where IN takes every result from the inner select and then runs the parenting query for each one (as far as I understand it). Besides, like I said, it is selecting the exact same fields for each query.

Also, which fields have you indexed? Fairly sure (from what I have gathered from reading your IRC communications) that you’re indexing pretty much all of them.

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @KO9 KO9
item.description:
@KO9 wrote:

This:

SELECT rscd_invitems.* FROM `rscd_players` left join (rscd_invitems) on (rscd_players.user = rscd_invitems.user) WHERE `login_ip` = '127.0.0.1'

Is MUCH faster than doing what you’re doing:

SELECT * FROM `rscd_invitems`
WHERE `owner`
IN (
        SELECT `owner` FROM `rscd_players`
        WHERE `login_ip` = '127.0.0.1'
        OR `creation_ip` = '127.0.0.1'
)
ORDER BY `id` ASC
LIMIT 0, 1000;

Proof:

mysql> SELECT * FROM rscd_invitems WHERE user IN ( SELECT user FROM rscd_players WHERE login_ip = ‘127.0.0.1’ OR creation_ip = ‘127.0.0.1’ ) ORDER BY id ASC LIMIT 0, 1000;
ERROR 1053 (08S01): Server shutdown in progress

I cancelled this query after 6 minutes because I didn’t want the tables inaccessible to find out exactly how long it would take to complete.

and my query:

mysql> SELECT rscd_invitems.* FROM rscd_players left join (rscd_invitems) on (rscd_players.user = rscd_invitems.user) WHERE login_ip = ‘127.0.0.1’;
Empty set (0.09 sec)

What it looks like when it returns (exactly the same):

mysql> SELECT rscd_invitems.* FROM `rscd_players` left join (rscd_invitems) on (rscd_players.user = rscd_invitems.user) WHERE `login_ip` = '0.0.0.0' limit 1;
+----------------+------+--------+---------+------+
| user           | id   | amount | wielded | slot |
+----------------+------+--------+---------+------+
| 71023123851000 |   10 |   1000 |       0 |    0 |
+----------------+------+--------+---------+------+
1 row in set (0.01 sec)

These are obviously really basic queries but it seems that most people on here have no-idea what SQL can do. When you have some queries to tweak and play around with you will soon fall in love.

Tweak them properly and you’ll fall in love even quicker ; )

Read full topic
